author: Staff Reporter
text:
The Madras High Court on Tuesday ordered notice to the State government on a petition moved by actor Simbu seeking to quash an FIR registered by the Central Crime Branch police, Chennai, over the “Beep” song row.

Two FIRs pending

According to the petitioner, two FIRs have been pending against him for allegedly circulating a music track online , with contents degrading the modesty of women. The FIRs were registered based on complaints filed by Coimbatore District Secretary of All India Democratic Women’s Association and Tamil Nadu Milk Vendors Association, Chennai, respectively.

On December 17, the actor moved a plea before the High Court seeking to quash the FIR registered against him by the Coimbatore Race Course police. While the petition is still pending before the court, Simbu has now approached the court to quash the second FIR filed by the Central Crime Branch police, Chennai.

Sees motive

The petitioner contended that the complainants who filed cases against him do not come under the definition of ‘aggrieved persons’ as contemplated under the Criminal Procedural Code . The actor also argued that since he was a well known and established actor in Tamil film industry, most of the complaints are made against him for the sake of publicity and to extract money from him.

Admitting the petition, Justice R. Subbiah directed notice to the Inspector of Police, Central Crime Branch, Cyber Crime, Chennai, and posted the matter to January 22 .

Actor says most of the complaints are made against him for publicity and extracting money
title: Simbu moves HC to quash one more FIR
